content.question: Two blocks, one of mass <math alttext="m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi></math> and one of mass <math alttext="2 m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mi>m</mi></math>, are free to move along a horizontal surface with negligible friction. The blocks undergo collisions in two separate scenarios. In the first scenario, the block of mass <math alttext="m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi></math> moves with an initial speed <math alttext="v sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> toward the block of mass <math alttext="2 m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mi>m</mi></math>, which is initially at rest, and the blocks stick together after they collide. In the second scenario, the block of mass <math alttext="2 m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mi>m</mi></math> moves with the same initial speed <math alttext="v sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> toward the block of mass <math alttext="m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi></math>, which is initially at rest, and the blocks again stick together after colliding. The total kinetic energy of the two-block system decreases by an amount <math alttext="delta K sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> in the first scenario and by <math alttext="delta K sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> in the second scenario. What is the ratio <math alttext="the fraction delta K sub 2 over delta K sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mrow><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><mrow><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow></mfrac></math> ?

skill.text: 2.D: Predict new values or factors of change of physical quantities using functional dependence between variables.
